57047.name: The Long Dark
description: The passageway seems to get darker, if that is possible.  Perhaps
it is that the granite has lost the flecks of other colors, and in
truty any trace of mithril, and now it seems to absorb all light.  The
granite is truly black now, pitch black.  This oppressive darkness is
what gives the Long Dark its name.

57066.name: The Round Chamber
description: This round chamber at the top of the Long Stair has three doors
leading off to the east, north and west.  Carven arches that were once
well decorated now stand to testify about the neglect this once
magnificent place has undergone.  The stone is scarred and pitted
where weapons have hacked at the carvings.  Once there may have been
directions to where each passage lead, but the stone placards have
been smashed beyond recognition.

57027.name: The First Neath
description: The First Neath curves around descending fron east to the south
here.  At a rough guess, you are probably a hundred feet below the
West Hall.  The path heads to the south into what is called the Second
Neath.  There are still no hints at mithril in the mine walls.

57032.name: {Y{#The Long Hall{x
description: The Long Hall stretches out to the north, west and east.  The
ceiling arches above you to a height of at least fifty feet.  Tall
stalagmites climb up from the floor of the cavern, while stalactites
descend from the ceiling.  The path winds across the cavern floor and
the Long Hall continues to the north, west and east.

57109.name: The Second Hall
description: Called the {Y{#Dawn Hall{x by some, the Second Hall is the first major
hall after the entering Moria from the {Y{#Dawn Gate{x.  The walls of the
Second Hall are covered entirely in a golden sandstone that when
coupled with the sunbursts inset in the floor, give the room a light
airy feel to it.  It was in this room that most outsiders were greeted
by the king upon being granted access to the city of Dwarrowdelf.  The
Second Hall stretches out to the south and east.

57148.name: A Soldier's Path
description: The Soldier's Path is so named as it was the road to the residences
of the defenders of Moria.  A peaceful city by most standards, they
were still subject to the jealousy of various nations with regards to
their wealth.  As such, the dwarves fought many battles to defend
their city, and in the end, although all dwarves were taught to fight
from a young age, they developed a Warrior's Caste.  It was here that
these Soldiers lived and trained.  For many, it was also here that
they died.

57288.name: The Path to Moria
description: The small windy path leading to the Gates or Moria edges around the
northwest corner of a stagnant black pool here.  Skeletal fingers of
long dead trees reach up from the pitch black waters.  The path is
bordered on one side by the black pool, and on the other by a high
grey cliff, not truly a cliff but the steeply rising side of the
mountain.  The path is covered in shale dust and chips that make
footing somewhat treacherous.

57175.name: The North Run
description: The North Run was dug chasing the first mithril vein discovered by
the dwarves of Moria.  The vein was a rich one, netting several
hundred pounds of ore.  The passageway slopes down from the south to
north.  The walls of the passageway are uneven, as the dwarves would
dig small pockets to get at the ore, leaving small alcoves.  Small
runes and what look like test holes are spaced along the walls.

57102.name: The Tomb of Balin
description: A shaft of {Wlight{x angles down into the center of this room
illuminating a single sarcophagus.  Inscribed on the lid are Dwarvish
Runes reading "Here lies Balin, Son of Fundin, King of Moria."
Corpses of dwarves in rusted armor lie scattered about the room, many
pierced with goblin arrows.  There are nine columns spaced about the
perimeter of the room, each representing one of the nine kings of
Moria.  Balin would have been the tenth.  The room has a small well
near the southern wall.

57245.name: Under the Bridge of Khazad-Dum in the Air
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  It is hard to make out any details
in this void, being able to see neither up, down or to the sides.
Floating in the black nothing of the Great Deep, never knowing when
you may smack into something unpleasant and hard.  Then again, perhaps
it will never happen.  Perhaps there is nothing above or below.
Perhaps none of this is real.  Then again...

57037.name: {Y{#The Long Hall{x
description: The Long Hall stretches out to the south, west and east.  The
ceiling arches above you to a height of at least fifty feet.  Tall
stalagmites climb up from the floor of the cavern, while stalactites
descend from the ceiling.  The path winds across the cavern floor and
the Long Hall continues to the south, west and east.

57044.name: Dorin's Peril
description: The passageway called Dorin's Peril is slightly wider than average.
Inlaid mithril in the wall over a small crevasse are the words:
{x
{W             "Here was the final resting place
{W             of Dorin, Son of Durin, King of Moria.
{W             He delved deep, following a rich vein
{W             of mithril.  With a mighty swing, his
{W             pick went through the wall, breaking
{W             away a large section, and carrying
{W             him to his death, in the depths
{W             below.  May the gods welcome him with
{W             ringing anvils."
{x
Mithril spiderwebbing crawls across the eastern wall.  To the south
lies the Oval Chamber and to the north, the passage continues.

57065.name: The Fifth Rise
description: The Fifth Rise is the top of the Long Stair.  The ceiling of the
cavern is about twenty feet above you.  The rise is a simple ten foot
landing, but this one, unlike the others has a short railing along the
outside edges.  To the north is a round chamber and the long stair
descends to the south.

57161.name: A Soldier's Path
description: The Soldier's Path is so named as it was the road to the residences
of the defenders of Moria.  A peaceful city by most standards, they
were still subject to the jealousy of various nations with regards to
their wealth.  As such, the dwarves fought many battles to defend
their city, and in the end, although all dwarves were taught to fight
from a young age, they developed a Warrior's Caste.  It was here that
these Soldiers lived and trained.  For many, it was also here that
they died.

57279.name: An Underground River
description: The underground river curves around from the east to the south
here.  The black water rushes around the corner, undercutting the
granite of the western wall.  A sheer granite walls rise to the north
and west.  In the inky depths, strange white shapes can be seen
moving.

57223.name: In the Air over the Great Deep
description: In the air off the Bridge of Khazad-Dum.  The chasm called the
Great Deep stretches out below.  No one is exactly sure how deep it
goes, only that it is deep.  Rumor has it that if one fell, they would
be able to count to at least twenty slowly before hitting bottom, but
to the best knowledge, no one has tested it.  The bridge of Khazad-Dum
lies just to the south.

57070.name: The Carven Corridor
description: The passageways delved through the stone, tunnels is perhaps a
better term, give way to a worked stone corridor here.  The walls are
fitted stone, with the occasional archway going over the passageway,
lending support and decoration.  Every stone has some adornment here.
It is a completely different feel than the other passageways.  If it
weren't for the perpetual dark, this might actually seem like a city.

57022.name: The First Neath
description: The first neath continues to slope down to the north.  Although it
is no longer below the East Run passage, it is probably still called
this for lack of a better name and to delineate it from the
surrounding stone and passages.  The downward slope moderates as the
passage moves farther to the north.

57280.name: An Underground River
description: The underground river curves around from the north to the west,
undercutting the southern wall.  The black water rushes between the
narrowing walls, and a strange gurgling sound can be heard to the
southwest.  In the depths, strange white shapes can be seen darting
here and there.

57246.name: In the Air of the Great Deep
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  It is hard to make out any details
in this void, being able to see neither up, down or to the sides.
Floating in the black nothing of the Great Deep, never knowing when
you may smack into something unpleasant and hard.  Then again, perhaps
it will never happen.  Perhaps there is nothing above or below.
Perhaps none of this is real.  Then again...

57191.name: The South Run
description: The South Run was one of the first mithril runs discovered by the
dwarves of Moria.  The run continues sloping down from west to east,
descending as it travels deeper into the mountain.  The walls and
ceiling of these passageway are uneven in their width, but the floor
is at least somewhat level.  The granite of the walls is slightly
becoming a slightly {C{^l{c{6i{Bgh{c{6t{C{^er blue{x than the previous passageway.
The stone is getting lighter as you travel deeper into the mountain.
Small flecks of the precious mithril reflect light here and there
across the wall.

57014.name: {Y{#The West Hall{x (Southwest)
description: This corner of the West Hall is covered in dust and the remains of
what may have once been an armory.  There is a rusted anvil in one
portion, and vairous chain links scattered about among the debris.
Walkways wind between piles of rotten wood and crumbling stone, but
there is nothing of use that has not already been scavenged here.

57089.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.

57222.name: In the Air over the Great Deep
description: In the air off the Bridge of Khazad-Dum.  The chasm called the
Great Deep stretches out below.  No one is exactly sure how deep it
goes, only that it is deep.  Rumor has it that if one fell, they would
be able to count to at least twenty slowly before hitting bottom, but
to the best knowledge, no one has tested it.  The bridge of Khazad-Dum
lies just to the south.

57074.name: The Broad Hall
description: The eastern Broad Hall stands just beyone the columns.  Barrel
vaults arch gracefully across the ceiling lending both support and
character to the hall.  Carvings continue along the walls, getting mor
intricate if possible, as they approach the Archway of Dwarrowdelf to
the east.  The hall continues to the north, west and south, with the
pair of central pillars flanking the main path to the west.

57296.name: Weapons Smith
description: A Large central forge dominates the middle of the room.  Numerous
anvils stand spread around it.  There are hundreds of pegs on the
walls all still hung with various tongs and hammers, although none of
them seems quite whole.  It almost appears as if something
intentionally destroyed the tools in the room and bits of broken metal
are scattered everywhere.  In one corner is a scattered pile of bar
stock, but even that appears to have been picked through and the
remaining bars are bent at strange angles.  Amidst the broken tools
there appear to be broken weapons as well, leading to the belief that
this room was once occupied by the fabled Dwarven Weapons Smiths of
Moria.

57113.name: The Dawn Stair
description: The {Y{#Dawn Stair{x falls away below.  The cavern is absolutely
immense, and the stair leading down is similar to the long stair in
appearance.  The stair is approximately ten feet wide, easily allowing
three people to walk abreast, yet the lack of walls along the sides is
somewhat unnerving.  The stairs have been fit with precision, and the
graceful arches over the bottomless abyss below add a strange sense of
grace to the stair.  Each stair has a {Y{#Golden{x sunburst pattern inlaid
into the center of it.

57094.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.

57107.name: The Path of the Dawn
description: {Y{#The Path of Dawn{x continues to the west, and to the east lies the
Second Hall.  Called the way out by some, it leads to the Dawn Gate at
the eastern end of Moria.  There is a distinct sunburst pattern
replicated down center of the path in {Y{#Gold veined Marble{x.  Despite
the years, the floors are highly polished and the stone of the walls
remains in perfect condition.

57114.name: The Dawn Stair
description: The {Y{#Dawn Stair{x falls away below.  The cavern is absolutely
immense, and the stair leading down is similar to the long stair in
appearance.  The stair is approximately ten feet wide, easily allowing
three people to walk abreast, yet the lack of walls along the sides is
somewhat unnerving.  The stairs have been fit with precision, and the
graceful arches over the bottomless abyss below add a strange sense of
grace to the stair.  Each stair has a {Y{#Golden{x sunburst pattern inlaid
into the center of it.  Above waits the top of the stair.

57078.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns must number in the hundreds, for this chamber is vast.  At one
time, this was the heart of the dwarven city.  It was a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves plied
their craft, smelting the precious mithril ores and crafting it into
works of art.  It was also here that they ate, drank, and lived.
Unfortunately, something happened, and many of them also died here.
Many a dwarf has sworn to gain back the wealth of Moria and return
Dwarrowdelf to it's greatness, but none speak of its fall, or what
precipitated it.  Now, the hold is as a massive tomb; dark, cold,
forgotten.

57072.name: The Broad Hall
description: The Northwest corner of the Broad Hall continues the carvings seen
at the western entrance.  The work is magnificent, what hasn't fallen
to ruin over the centuries at least.  The support columns are both to
the southeast, and it appears as if there are some ruined buildings
along the north wall of the hall.

57009.name: {Y{#The West Hall{x (North)
description: The West Hall was once the center of commerce for the dwarves of
this ancient city.  It was here that the craftsmen set up booths to
sell their wares to those from outside Moria.  For many, this large
hall was as far as they ever saw into the depths of Moria, for the
dwarves guarded their wealth jealously.  From here, one could not even
hear hammer on stone as more and more tunnels were delved, nor could
one hear the din of those who lived in the city of Moria.  Outsiders
came to purchase the famed mithril wares of the dwarves.  To the
south, and in the center of this large chamber, you can just make out
the large central column.

57084.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.

57088.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.

57140.name: A Strange Room
description: The walls of this room are stone, but the manufacture is not
dwarvish.  They have the feeling of something much older.  Arcane
symbols and desgins inlaid in what appears to be mithril cover the
walls.  There is not a single inch that is not touched by these
markings.  A low stone platform, reminiscent of a bed rests against
the eastern wall, it too is covered with the strange symbols.  The
whole room has the feeling of a tomb, or worse yet, a prison.

57035.name: {Y{#The Long Hall{x
description: The Long Hall stretches out to the north, west and east.  The
ceiling arches above you to a height of at least fifty feet.  Tall
stalagmites climb up from the floor of the cavern, while stalactites
descend from the ceiling.  The path winds across the cavern floor and
the Long Hall continues to the north, west and east.

57034.name: {Y{#The Long Hall{x
description: The Long Hall stretches out to the south, west and east.  The
ceiling arches above you to a height of at least fifty feet.  Tall
stalagmites climb up from the floor of the cavern, while stalactites
descend from the ceiling.  The path winds across the cavern floor and
the Long Hall continues to the south, west and east.

57055.name: The Long Stair
description: Standing on the Long Stair, you can look up towards the heights of
the cavern, lost in the inky blackness above.  Below, the river is
fading as your light does not penetrate that far down.  The stair is
of cut granite stones and arches so finely crafted it is hard to see
the mortar in the joints.  The stairs themselves are nearly ten feet
wide, easily allowing two or three people to pass at once, but the
lack of walls along the sides is a bit disconcerting.  It might be
best to walk up the center of the stair, just to be safe.  Far below
you see the landing called the First Rise, while the landing at the
Second Rise waits to the north.

57158.name: A Soldier's House
description: A Spartan Soldier's House, more of a barracks room really.  There
are three narrow stone pallets, beside which are a small stone table.
There is a book niche beside each pallet that may have once held
precious possessions or a lamp.  Stone pegs are scattered about the
wall, obviously for hanging the implements of their trade, as well as
the occasionally needed cloak.  The room has a somewhat oppressive air
to it.

57290.name: Approaching the Mines of Moria
description: This path is small and slowly winds down along the flank of the
mountain.  The footing is somewhat treacherous as it winds down,
attributed to a bit of shale and other rock debris.  The landscape
becomes more barren as one winds down and further down the path is
something that reflects the light, looking somewhat like water.  The
trees are scragly and windblown along this part of the trail, but to
the best of knowledge, this is the only path to Moria.

57221.name: The Priest's Chambers
description: The private chambers of the Priest of Moradin, patron of Dwarves
and Smiths.  The walls of the room are covered in an intricate design
of carved anvils and hammers.  There is a small alcove with an anvil
still standing in it along the eastern wall.  The anvil is covered in
Dwarven Runes and looks to be solid mithril.  A stone pallet rests
along the western wall, and a writing desk stands beside the door to
the north.

57151.name: A Soldier's Path
description: The Soldier's Path is so named as it was the road to the residences
of the defenders of Moria.  A peaceful city by most standards, they
were still subject to the jealousy of various nations with regards to
their wealth.  As such, the dwarves fought many battles to defend
their city, and in the end, although all dwarves were taught to fight
from a young age, they developed a Warrior's Caste.  It was here that
these Soldiers lived and trained.  For many, it was also here that
they died.  Soldier's houses lie both to the north and south.

57052.name: The Long Stair
description: Standing near the bottom of the Long Stair, you can look up towards
the heights of the cavern, lost in the inky blackness above.  The
stair is of cut granite stones and arches so finely crafted it is hard
to see the mortar in the joints.  The stairs themselves are nearly ten
feet wide, easily allowing two or three people to pass at once, but
the lack of walls along the sides is a bit disconcerting.  It might be
best to walk up the center of the stair, just to be safe.  Below you
see a stone bridge arching over the black ribbon of an underground
river.

57190.name: The South Run
description: The South Run was one of the first mithril runs discovered by the
dwarves of Moria.  The run curves downward from the north and turns to
the east here, descending as it climbs deeper into the mountain.  The
walls and ceiling of these passageway are uneven in their width, but
the floor is at least somewhat level.  The granite of the walls is
slightly becoming a slightly {c{6l{Bighte{c{6r b{Blu{c{6e{x than the {Bmidnight blue{x
of the previous passageway.  The stone is getting lighter as you
travel deeper into the mountain.  Small flecks of the precious mithril
reflect light here and there across the wall.

57169.name: The War Hall
description: The War Hall was where the Soldiers of Moria met to discuss matters
of defense of the city, as well as to train.  The hall is large enough
for the whole fighting force to pratice with axes, crossbows or
whatever else they may need.  Scars pit the floor where weapons of the
past made contact with the granite, and the remains of a balista stand
near a low wall with a large opening overlooking a stair in a massive
cavern.

57021.name: The First Neath
description: The First Neath is so named as it is below the level of the West
Hall and passes directly under part of the East Run.  The passage
becomes a bit more steep as it slopes down to the north.  The First
Neath continues down to the north, and the East Run winds up to the
south.

57277.name: An Underground River
description: The underground river continues from east to west.  The steady
current has eroded the granite walls on either side, and the walls
appear to be getting closer together to either side.  The black water
rushes through what has become a gorge, swirling and threatening to
sweep everything down stream.

57030.name: {Y{#The Long Hall{x
description: The Long Hall stretches out to the south And east.  You cannot see
the far side.  The ceiling arches above you to a height of at least
fifty feet.  Tall stalagmites climb up from the floor of the cavern,
while stalactites descend from the ceiling in a parody reminiscent of
a Dragon's maw.  The path winds across the cavern floor.  To the west
is the Second Neath, while the Long Hall continues to the east and
south.

57256.name: An Underground River
description: The dark water rushes down from the south, tumbling over rocks and
hidden obstacles as it cascades down to the south.  Eddies swirl in
small pockets of rock as the walls begin their sheer rise to either
side.  Occasionally, the surface is placid, as a deep pool gives some
relief from the rushing torrent of the surrounding water.

57170.name: The North Run
description: The North Run was dug chasing the first mithril vein discovered by
the dwarves of Moria.  The vein was a rich one, netting several
hundred pounds of ore.  The passageway moves from the West Hall to the
south and heads north, there are still small spiderwebs of mithril
glinting in the light.  The walls of the passageway are uneven, as the
dwarves would dig small pockets to get at the ore, leaving small
alcoves.  Small runes and what look like test holes are spaced along
the walls.

57241.name: In the Air In the Great Deep
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  Above and to the south lies the
Bridge of Khazad-Dum, a frail looking structure build by the dwarves
and used as a sort of under the mountain highway by them for
centuries.  From this angle, it is hard to believe that it could
support any weight at all, but then again, it was build by dwarves.
Inky blackness presses in from all around, bringing to mind the
numbing oblivion that is everywhere in this place.

57224.name: In the Air over the Great Deep
description: In the air off the Bridge of Khazad-Dum.  The chasm called the
Great Deep stretches out below.  No one is exactly sure how deep it
goes, only that it is deep.  Rumor has it that if one fell, they would
be able to count to at least twenty slowly before hitting bottom, but
to the best knowledge, no one has tested it.  The bridge of Khazad-Dum
lies just to the south.

57250.name: Bottom of the Great Deep
description: The bottom of the Great Deep.  The stone litter of centuries lies
strewn across the ground.  There is even the occasional glint of what
remains of something metal here or there, but exactly what it once was
is unknown.  The deep continues in all directions, and in the distance
water can be heard echoing off the walls of the chasm.

57244.name: Under the Bridge of Khazad-Dum in the Air
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  It is hard to make out any details
in this void, being able to see neither up, down or to the sides.
Floating in the black nothing of the Great Deep, never knowing when
you may smack into something unpleasant and hard.  Then again, perhaps
it will never happen.  Perhaps there is nothing above or below.
Perhaps none of this is real.  Then again...

57142.name: Stair to Mine Shaft 13
description: The stairs end in a flat landing here.  The scorch marks and soot
continue, and there is a scent in the air of something long dead.  The
passageway to the south looks to be about a ten foot square passage,
and the familiar mithril speckles once again adorn the walls.

57077.name: The Archway of Dwarrowdelf
description: The true entrance to the city of Dwarrowdelf.  The Archway once
held a stone gate, the remains of which lie shattered and blackened on
the floor.  Some incredible force broke these gates in.  The carvings
on the archway itself are incredible, those that remain intact, and
the use of different colors of stone, the vibrancy of which can still
be seen under the soot, is amazing.

57121.name: The Dawn Stair
description: The {Y{#Dawn Stair{x falls away below.  The cavern is absolutely
immense, and the stair leading down is similar to the long stair in
appearance.  The stair is approximately ten feet wide, easily allowing
three people to walk abreast, yet the lack of walls along the sides is
somewhat unnerving.  The stairs have been fit with precision, and the
graceful arches over the bottomless abyss below add a strange sense of
grace to the stair.  Each stair has a {Y{#Golden{x sunburst pattern inlaid
into the center of it.  The stair continues above and the First
Landing is to the east.

57227.name: In the Air over the Great Deep
description: In the air off the Bridge of Khazad-Dum.  The chasm called the
Great Deep stretches out below.  No one is exactly sure how deep it
goes, only that it is deep.  Rumor has it that if one fell, they would
be able to count to at least twenty slowly before hitting bottom, but
to the best knowledge, no one has tested it.  The bridge of Khazad-Dum
lies just to the north.

57255.name: An Underground River
description: The dark water rushes down from the north, tumbling over rocks and
hidden obstacles.  Eddies swirl in small pockets of rock as the walls
begin their sheer rise to either side.  Occasionally, the surface is
placid, as a deep pool gives some relief from the rushing torrent of
the surrounding water.

57174.name: The North Run
description: The North Run was dug chasing the first mithril vein discovered by
the dwarves of Moria.  The vein was a rich one, netting several
hundred pounds of ore.  The passageway curves around from the east to
the south, sloping downward as it goes.  The walls of the passageway
are uneven, as the dwarves would dig small pockets to get at the ore,
leaving small alcoves.  Small runes and what look like test holes are
spaced along the walls.

57118.name: The Dawn Stair
description: The {Y{#Dawn Stair{x falls away below.  The cavern is absolutely
immense, and the stair leading down is similar to the long stair in
appearance.  The stair is approximately ten feet wide, easily allowing
three people to walk abreast, yet the lack of walls along the sides is
somewhat unnerving.  The stairs have been fit with precision, and the
graceful arches over the bottomless abyss below add a strange sense of
grace to the stair.  Each stair has a {Y{#Golden{x sunburst pattern inlaid
into the center of it.  The Second Landing is to the north, while the
stair continues above.

57076.name: The Broad Hall
description: The southwest corner of the Broad Hall remains covered with
carvings.  There seems to be a theme in this corner dealing with
commerce and the sale of common, everyday items.  As with the whole
room, the carvings are spread throughout the area.  Small buildings or
shops, at least the remains of them, are spread along the south wall
of the Hall.  The hall continues to the north and east.

57124.name: West Rim of the Great Deep
description: The west edge of the great deep is where the Bridge of Khazad-Dum
reaches the bottom of the {Y{#Dawn Stair.  {x It is a simple landing in a
wedge shape moving from the ten foot width at the base of the stair to
the three foot width of the bridge.  Continuing with the theme on the
whole {Y{#Dawn path{X there is a {Y{#Sunburst{x pattern in the center of the
room.

57045.name: The Long Dark
description: The passageway seems to get darker, if that is possible.  Perhaps
it is that the granite has lost the flecks of other colors, and in
truth any trace of mithril, and now it seems to absorb all light.  The
granite is truly black now, pitch black.  This oppressive darkness is
what gives the Long Dark its name.

57208.name: Dorin's Crevasse
description: The walls of the Dorin's Crevasse are natural stone, never having
seen the bite of pick, chisel or drill.  They are uneven granite,
varying from ten to thirty feet wide.  Dorin's fall to the depths must
have been a terrible one.

57179.name: Mine Shaft One
description: The botton of Shaft One.  As with all the passages thus far, there
is a dusting of mithril in the walls, but nothing significant.
Probably not enough mithril here to even gather together into a single
coin.  The test holes and alcoves where mithril was taken out have
reappeared in the walls, and the floor is fairly even.  The mine
continues to the north.

57167.name: The War Hall
description: The War Hall was where the Soldiers of Moria met to discuss matters
of defense of the city, as well as to train.  The hall is large enough
for the whole fighting force to pratice with axes, crossbows or
whatever else they may need.  Scars pit the floor where weapons of the
past made contact with the granite, and the remains of a balista stand
near a low wall with a large opening overlooking a stair in a massive
cavern.

57056.name: The Second Rise
description: The second landing up fromt he bottom of this enormouse cavern is
named the Second Rise.  It is one of the five climbing up into the
heights of this massive cavern.  The landing is a simple ten foot
square, providing a great location for a rest.  The clim

57237.name: Air Under the Bridge of Khazad-Dum
description: The bridge of Khazad-Dum lies directly above, while below there is
only empty space.  A sheer wall lies to the east.  Looking at it from
underneath, it is hard to believe the bridge spanning that distance
could support any weight at all, but then again, it was constructed by
the dwarves.  Blackness surrounds in all directions.

57286.name: Dorin's Well
description: The bottom of Dorin's Well.  Rather than a well holding water, it
appears as if this well were a sort of treasury.  Unfortunately, most
everything has been pillaged from it over the years.  The walls are
worked stone and niches along the wall, as well as empty pegs hint at
this place's former purpose.  A few bits of rusted metal litter the
floor, and occasionally small glints are seen reflecting the light.

57135.name: Stair to Mine Shaft 12
description: The spiral stair ends in a mine shaft, Shaft Twelve to be exact.  A
faint twinkling in the walls denotes traces of mithril left behind by
the mining operations.  The cobwebs that darkened the staircase
continue through this part of the mine, and there is a faint breeze
weezing down the passageway.

57177.name: Mine Shaft One
description: Near the top of Mine Shaft One, there remains a tracery of mithril
along the walls.  It looks like the vein the dwarves were following
took a downward turn.  As you descend the shaft, the absence of runes
seems conspicuous.

57239.name: Air Under the Bridge of Khazad-Dum
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  The bridge of Khazad-Dum is directly
above, while a sheer wall lies to the west.  Looking at it from
underneath, it is hard to believe teh bridge spanning that distance
could support any weight at all, but then again, it was constructed by
the dwarves.  Blackness surrounds in all directions.

57189.name: The South Run
description: The South Run was one of the first mithril runs discovered by the
dwarves of Moria.  The run extends from the southwest corner of the
West Hall some distance into the mountain.  The walls and ceiling of
these passageway are uneven in their width, but the floor is at least
somewhat level.  The granite of the walls is slightly more grey than
the black of most of Moria, and looking really closely, they appear to
be closer to {Bmidnight blue{x than black.  Small flecks of the precious
mithril reflect light here and there across the wall.

57271.name: An Underground River
description: THe river curves around from the east to the south here.  It is
wide and black, although a deafening roar can be heard building to the
southwest, almost as if it were building to a waterfall.  The black
water moves quickly here, but appears as if one could easily swim it
if need be.  The granite walls are wide here, reaching nearly twenty
feet.  To the east there appears to be a rocky shoreline.

57193.name: Mine Shaft Two
description: Shaft 2 of Moria seems to be more of a quarry than a mine for
precious minerals.  There is no hint of mithril, and the flecks and
runes marking the mithril halls are absent here.  Instead, the walls
are perfect squares, attesting to the quarrying nature of what was
done here.  This {C{^blue granite{x must have been worth something if the
dwarves were willing to trade in digging for mithril for quarrying
this stuff.

57058.name: The Long Stair
description: Standing on the Long Stair, you can look up towards the heights of
the cavern, lost in the inky blackness above.  Below the view is much
the same, the bottom of the cavern lost in the darkness.  The stair is
of cut granite stones and arches so finely crafted it is hard to see
the mortar in the joints.  The stairs themselves are nearly ten feet
wide, easily allowing two or three people to pass at once, but the
lack of walls along the sides is a bit disconcerting.  It might be
best to walk up the center of the stair, just to be safe.  Far below
you see the landing called the Second Rise, while the landing at the
Third Rise lies just to the north.

57234.name: The Bottom of the Great Deep
description: The southeast corner of the Great Deep.  Rock litter is strewn
across the bottom of the chasm, and water can be heard faintly in the
distance.  The inky blackness of the chasm is oppressive and it feels
as if the weight of the mountain is about to come tumbling down.  It
is almost claustrophobic, the black basalt, the granite, the weight of
a whole mountain resting upon this little space.

57263.name: An Underground River
description: Dark water swirls from the east and curves around to the north,
undercutting the stone of the western wall.  The splash and gurgle of
the water is nearly deafening, and a froth is beaten up as the water
comes into contact with the sheer faces of granite.  The underground
river curves from the east and sloshes up to the north here.

57293.name: Entrance to the Forges
description: The entrance to the Dwarven Forges still holds the smell of molten
metal in the air, although now, there is also another overlying
stench.  An odor that doesn't quite belong.  A mixture of Goblin and
strangely what you might only describe as brimstone.  Metal shavings
cover the floor and crunch softly underfoot.  While the dust is thick,
there are footprints of other things that have passed this way.  From
the look of them, unwholesome things...

57138.name: A Strange Room
description: The walls of this room are stone, but the manufacture is not
dwarvish.  They have the feeling of something much older.  Arcane
symbols and desgins inlaid in what appears to be mithril cover the
walls and what is left of the northern door.  There is not a single
inch that is not touched by these markings.  The whole room has the
feeling of a tomb, or worse yet, a prison.

57028.name: The Second Neath
description: The Second Neath is named as the second passage under the level of
the West Hall.  The Second Neath continues sloping down around the
corner and to the east.  In the distance, you can hear the echoes of
your footfalls.  It sounds like the passage opens up to the east.  To
the north lies the First Neath.

57287.name: Balrog's Holding Pen
description: This is the Balrog's Holding Pen...  If you have arrived here...
It is by mistake...

57228.name: In the Air in the Great Deep
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  The bridge of Khazad-Dum is above
and to the north, and the sheer walls of the great deep rise and fall
to both the east and south.  Exactly how far it is to the bottom of
the deep is unknown.

57258.name: An Underground River
description: The dark water rushes down from the east, tumbling over rocks and
hidden obstacles as it cascades down to the south.  Eddies swirl in
small pockets of rock as the walls begin their sheer rise to either
side.  Occasionally, the surface is placid, as a deep pool gives some
relief from the rushing torrent of the surrounding water.

57096.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.

57289.name: Near the Black Pool
description: The small windy path leading to the Gates or Moria edges around the
western edge of a stagnant black pool here.  Skeletal fingers of long
dead trees reach up from the pitch black waters.  The path is bordered
on one side by the black pool, and on the other by a high grey cliff,
not truly a cliff but the steeply rising side of the mountain.  The
path is covered in shale dust and chips that make footing somewhat
treacherous.

57261.name: An Underground River
description: The river undercuts the northern wall as it spins around from the
south and heads west.  The dark water is moving extremely rapidly,
making loud crashing sounds as it erodes the northern wall.  Flecks of
foam are churned up by the incessant crashing upon the rocks, only to
swirl away to the west.  The river continues to the south.

57236.name: The Bottom of the Great Deep
description: The floor is littered with debris, as if portions of the walls had
fallen off and deposited themselves.  The occasional boulder lurks
ominously in the dark.  The granite is speckled with crystals that
reflect the light back in many directions.  The bottom of the Great
Deep continues to the north and east, while sheer walls rise to the
south and west.

57011.name: {Y{#The West Hall{x (East)
description: The West Hall was once the center of commerce for the dwarves of
this ancient city.  It was here that the craftsmen set up booths to
sell their wares to those from outside Moria.  For many, this large
hall was as far as they ever saw into the depths of Moria, for the
dwarves guarded their wealth jealously.  From here, one could not even
hear hammer on stone as more and more tunnels were delved, nor could
one hear the din of those who lived in the city of Moria.  All the
same, it was here that the majority of currency changed hands as
outsiders came to purchase the famed mithril wares of the dwarves.  To
the west, and in the center of this large chamber, you can just make
out the large central column.

57266.name: An Underground River
description: The underground river continues from east to west.  The steady
current has eroded the granite walls on either side, and the walls
appear to be getting closer together to either side.  The black water
rushes through what has become a gorge, swirling and threatening to
sweep everything down stream.

57141.name: Stair to Mine Shaft 13
description: The spiral stair continues.  Rock dust and chips coat the stairs as
if some sort of earth tremor had occured fairly recently.  The walls
and ceiling are covered in old soot, and cobwebs cling to the ceiling.

57173.name: The North Run
description: The North Run was dug chasing the first mithril vein discovered by
the dwarves of Moria.  The vein was a rich one, netting several
hundred pounds of ore.  The passageway slopes down from the east to
west.  The walls of the passageway are uneven, as the dwarves would
dig small pockets to get at the ore, leaving small alcoves.  Small
runes and what look like test holes are spaced along the walls.

57106.name: The Path of the Dawn
description: {Y{#The Path of Dawn{x continues to the east and west here.  Called the
way out by some, it leads to the Dawn Gate at the eastern end of
Moria.  There is a distinct sunburst pattern replicated down center of
the path in {Y{#Gold veined Marble{x.  Despite the years, the floors are
highly polished and the stone of the walls remains in perfect
condition.

57149.name: A Soldier's Path
description: The path curves from the north around to the east here.  The
Soldier's Path is so named as it was the road to the residences of the
defenders of Moria.  A peaceful city by most standards, they were
still subject to the jealousy of various nations with regards to their
wealth.  As such, the dwarves fought many battles to defend their
city, and in the end, although all dwarves were taught to fight from a
young age, they developed a Warrior's Caste.  It was here that these
Soldiers lived and trained.  For many, it was also here that they
died.

57225.name: In the Air over the Great Deep
description: In the air off the Bridge of Khazad-Dum.  The chasm called the
Great Deep stretches out below.  No one is exactly sure how deep it
goes, only that it is deep.  Rumor has it that if one fell, they would
be able to count to at least twenty slowly before hitting bottom, but
to the best knowledge, no one has tested it.  The bridge of Khazad-Dum
lies just to the north.

57146.name: Mine Shaft 13
description: The passageway continues north and terminates here, and the thin
mithril veins have grown steadily to become substantial veins through
the granite.  In the southern wall, there is a small hole from which
exudes a foul odor of something long dead.  Intere long dead.
Interestingly, some of the rock chips around this small hole show bits
and pieces of strange runes.  Upon closer examination of the rock, the
workmanship does not seem to be dwarven.

57199.name: Mine Shaft Two
description: This alcove is more of a cut-out of blue stone.  The walls are
still square and remain the same {C{^light blue{x color.  For some reason,
the dwarves just stopped cutting stone here.  The quarry goes back to
the central shaft to the west.

57229.name: In the Air in the Great Deep
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  The bridge of Khazad-Dum is above
and to the north, and the sheer walls of the great deep rise and fall
to the south.  The vastness of the deep is evident in the darkness all
about.  Exactly how far it is to the bottom of the deep is unknown.

57196.name: Mine Shaft Two
description: The shaft drops down here, remaining a perfect square as it goes
downward.  Drill holes can still be seen, attesting to the fact that
this was once a stone quarry for the {C{^light blue granite{x that you
have seen in the previous passageways.  The dwarves must have been
following some quality in the stone that you cannot comprehend, for
the present walls look the same all around, and there are no clues as
to why they delved down instead of continuing in the direction they
had been.

57123.name: The Dawn Stair
description: The {Y{#Dawn Stair{x rises away above.  The cavern is absolutely
immense, and the stair leading down is similar to the long stair in
appearance.  The stair is approximately ten feet wide, easily allowing
three people to walk abreast, yet the lack of walls along the sides is
somewhat unnerving.  The stairs have been fit with precision, and the
graceful arches over the bottomless abyss below add a strange sense of
grace to the stair.  Each stair has a {Y{#Golden{x sunburst pattern inlaid
into the center of it.  In the distance to the east is the great deep
where you can just make out a narrow bridge.

57145.name: Mine Shaft 13
description: The passageway continues north and south here, and the thin mithril
veins are growing steadily in size.  The walls and ceilings show soot
and blackening, possibly from some ancient fire that raged through
this area.  The floor is littered with rock chips and dust and the
ceiling is very fractured.

57282.name: An Underground River
description: The underground river curves around from the north to the west
here, narrowing slightly as it goes.  The black water continues to
rush below, and to the southwest there is a strange gurgling sound.
The surface of the water has been whipped to a froth here, and it is
impossible to see the true color of the turbid water.  Sheer walls
rise to either side, all in black granite with some silver tracery.

57212.name: A Soldier's House
description: A Spartan Soldier's House, more of a barracks room really.  There
are three narrow stone pallets, beside which are a small stone table.
There is a book niche beside each pallet that may have once held
precious possessions or a lamp.  Stone pegs are scattered about the
wall, obviously for hanging the implements of their trade, as well as
the occasionally needed cloak.  The room has a somewhat oppressive air
to it.

57043.name: The Oval Chamber
description: The Oval Chamber is approximately twenty feet long by twelve feet
wide, in truth, only slightly wider than the passageways, but enough
to be noticable.  The walls and floor here are smooth as glass, as if
melted by some huge fire.  Interestingly, in the smooth black surface,
there are pinpricks of the brightest silver, what you take to be
mithril, twinkling like stars in the black obsidian of the walls and
floor.  The Drawing Dark lies to the south, while north lies Dorin's
Peril.

57083.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.

57104.name: The Path of the Dawn
description: {Y{#The Path of Dawn{x curves from south to east here.  Called the way
out by some, it leads to the Dawn Gate at the eastern end of Moria.
There is a distinct sunburst pattern replicated down center of the
path in {Y{#Gold veined Marble{x.  Despite the years, the floors are
highly polished and the stone of the walls remains in perfect
condition.

57284.name: An Underground River
description: The narrow defile curves around to the east to the south.  The
white water continues to churn below and that strange gurgling sound
in nearly deafening in volume now.  The luminescent moss grows even
thicker here, adding its own light to the gorge's sheer granite walls.

57203.name: Dorin's Crevasse
description: The walls of the Dorin's Crevasse are natural stone, never having
seen the bite of pick, chisel or drill.  They are uneven granite,
varying from ten to thirty feet wide.  Dorin's fall to the depths must
have been a terrible one.

57038.name: {Y{#The Long Hall{x
description: The northeastern corner of the Long Hall.  You cannot see the
western end of the hall due to the staggering number of stalagmites
and stalactites.  A path winds through the field of stone dragon's
teeth, and you occasionally catch the glimpse of some crystal
formation.  To the south is what appears to be an exit from the Long
Hall, while the hall continues to the west.

57231.name: In the Air in the Great Deep
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  It is hard to make out any details
in this void, being able to see neither up, down or to the sides.
Floating in the black nothing of the Great Deep, never knowing when
you may smack into something unpleasant and hard.  Then again, perhaps
it will never happen.  Perhaps there is nothing above or below.
Perhaps none of this is real.  Then again...

57122.name: The First Landing
description: The first landing lies atop the first set of stairs from the level
of the bridge over the great deep.  The landing is a simple square of
about ten feet.  A five foot {Y{#Sunburst{x decorates the center of the
landing and it looks like solid gold inlay.  The stair continues up to
the west or down below you.

57180.name: Mine Shaft One
description: The twisting passageways of Moria's Mine Shaft One.  This was the
first vein of mithril discovered by the dwarves of Moria.  It is
rumored that the vein never ran out, but slowed enough that the
dwarves found other more profitable digs.  The walls are of black
granite, and the mithril stands out easily in the light.

57105.name: The Path of the Dawn
description: {Y{#The Path of Dawn{x continues to the east and west here.  Called the
way out by some, it leads to the Dawn Gate at the eastern end of
Moria.  There is a distinct sunburst pattern replicated down center of
the path in {Y{#Gold veined Marble{x.  Despite the years, the floors are
highly polished and the stone of the walls remains in perfect
condition.

57053.name: The First Rise
description: The First Rise, so named as it is the first landing up from the
bottom of this enormous cavern.  The landing is a simple ten foot
square, providing a relatively safe location to rest.  Down to the
south the bottom of the cavern is visible, with an underground river
and a small bridge.  The long stair continues to climb upward.

57115.name: The Dawn Stair
description: The {Y{#Dawn Stair{x falls away below.  The cavern is absolutely
immense, and the stair leading down is similar to the long stair in
appearance.  The stair is approximately ten feet wide, easily allowing
three people to walk abreast, yet the lack of walls along the sides is
somewhat unnerving.  The stairs have been fit with precision, and the
graceful arches over the bottomless abyss below add a strange sense of
grace to the stair.  Each stair has a {Y{#Golden{x sunburst pattern inlaid
into the center of it.  The stair continues upwards, while to the east
lies the Third Landing.

57270.name: An Underground River
description: The river narrows as it passes to the west, coming to a point where
the average man could reach out his arms and touch both sides at the
same time.  The turbid black water rushes below, and there is an echo
coming from the east, almost as if there is a large cavern opening up.
The river curves from the north around to the west here.

57087.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.

57176.name: The North Run
description: The North Run terminates here with a simple shaft descending down
Mine Shaft One.  Based upon the debris around the edge of the shaft,
it looks like there was once a winch of some sort here.  The shaft
drops down out of sight, and the North Run continues to the south.

57004.name: First Rise (Lower)
description: The passageway rises to the east, climbing higher and higher into
the mountain.  Although the path is going up, you still know that the
sheer amount of stone over your head is staggering.  To the west lies
the main entrance to the mines.  The slope is gradual, allowing for an
easy ascent.

57031.name: {Y{#The Long Hall{x
description: The Long Hall stretches out to the north and east.  You cannot see
the far side.  The ceiling arches above you to a height of at least
fifty feet.  Tall stalagmites climb up from the floor of the cavern,
while stalactites descend from the ceiling in a parody reminiscent of
a Dragon's maw.  The path winds across the cavern floor and the Long
Hall continues to the north and east.

57243.name: Under the Bridge of Khazad-Dum in the Air
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  It is hard to make out any details
in this void, being able to see neither up, down or to the sides.
Floating in the black nothing of the Great Deep, never knowing when
you may smack into something unpleasant and hard.  Then again, perhaps
it will never happen.  Perhaps there is nothing above or below.
Perhaps none of this is real.  Then again...

57172.name: The North Run
description: The North Run was dug chasing the first mithril vein discovered by
the dwarves of Moria.  The vein was a rich one, netting several
hundred pounds of ore.  The passageway heads curves around, sloping
from the south to the west.  The walls of the passageway are uneven,
as the dwarves would dig small pockets to get at the ore, leaving
small alcoves.  Small runes and what look like test holes are spaced
along the walls.

57110.name: The Second Hall
description: Called the {Y{#Dawn Hall{x by some, the Second Hall is the first major
hall after the entering Moria from the {Y{#Dawn Gate{x.  The walls of the
Second Hall are covered entirely in a golden sandstone that when
coupled with the sunbursts inset in the floor, give the room a light
airy feel to it.  It was in this room that most outsiders were greeted
by the king upon being granted access to the city of Dwarrowdelf.  The
Second Hall stretches out to the south and west, while the Graven Arch
lies to the east.

57272.name: An Underground River
description: An Underground river curves around from the north to the west here.
To the east there is a rocky shoreline, that appears to be part of
some huge cavern.  The river is wide here, nearly fourty feet across,
ending in a sheer granite wall.  The water is black, and in the
depths, occasional white shapes are seen swimming.

57018.name: The East Run
description: The East Run was delved following one of the first mithril veins in
Moria.  Here the walls are fairly rough, and you can still see some
silver tracings winding through the stone.  The dwarves appear to have
abandoned the thin veins of mithril in these passage as too much work
for too little gain.  Now, one shall never know.  The passage curves
from west around to the south and continues sloping down.

57187.name: Mine Shaft One
description: The twisting passageways of Moria's Mine Shaft One.  This was the
first vein of mithril discovered by the dwarves of Moria.  It is
rumored that the vein never ran out, but slowed enough that the
dwarves found other more profitable digs.  The walls are of black
granite, and the mithril stands out easily in the light.

57143.name: Mine Shaft 13
description: The passageway curves from the north to the east here, and the
mithril speckles that adorned the walls in the previous passageway
have now increased to spidery veins.  The walls and ceiling are still
showing soot and blackening, and the rock chips and dust continue
throughout the area.

57025.name: The First Neath
description: The first neath continues to slope down around the curve to the
south.  Although it is no longer below the East Run passage, it is
probably still called this for lack of a better name.  The path
continues unchanging as the stone around it.

57091.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.

57206.name: Dorin's Crevasse
description: The walls of the Dorin's Crevasse are natural stone, never having
seen the bite of pick, chisel or drill.  They are uneven granite,
varying from ten to thirty feet wide.  Dorin's fall to the depths must
have been a terrible one.

57160.name: A Soldier's House
description: A Spartan Soldier's House, more of a barracks room really.  There
are three narrow stone pallets, beside which are a small stone table.
There is a book niche beside each pallet that may have once held
precious possessions or a lamp.  Stone pegs are scattered about the
wall, obviously for hanging the implements of their trade, as well as
the occasionally needed cloak.  The room has a somewhat oppressive air
to it.

57268.name: An Underground River
description: The narrow gorge curves around from the west to the north.  It is
narrow enough now that reaching one's arms out to either side, the
average man could touch both sides.  The granite is eroded from
millenia of water crashing through the defile, and the black water is
covered in a white froth.

57165.name: The War Hall
description: The War Hall was where the Soldiers of Moria met to discuss matters
of defense of the city, as well as to train.  The hall is large enough
for the whole fighting force to pratice with axes, crossbows or
whatever else they may need.  Scars pit the floor where weapons of the
past made contact with the granite, and the remains of a balista stand
near a low wall with a large opening overlooking a stair in a massive
cavern.

57005.name: First Rise (Middle)
description: The passageway continues up to the east and down to the west.  The
granite remains rough hewn, yet the skill of those who delved these
passages cannot be denied.  Further up the passage to the west you can
hear the sound of dripping water.

57016.name: The East Run
description: The East Run was delved following one of the first mithril veins in
Moria.  Here the walls are fairly rough, and you can still see some
silver tracings winding through the stone.  The tunnel slopes down to
the east, and to the west side, opens into the West Hall.

57152.name: A Soldier's Path
description: The Soldier's Path is so named as it was the road to the residences
of the defenders of Moria.  A peaceful city by most standards, they
were still subject to the jealousy of various nations with regards to
their wealth.  As such, the dwarves fought many battles to defend
their city, and in the end, although all dwarves were taught to fight
from a young age, they developed a Warrior's Caste.  It was here that
these Soldiers lived and trained.  For many, it was also here that
they died.  Soldier's houses lie both to the north and south.

57253.name: The Bottom of the Great Deep
description: An underground river lies to the north, its waters lapping hungrily
at the stone at the edge of the room.  The current moves rapidly by,
and the dampness has provided the perfect atmosphere for slime and
moss to grow thickly upon the stones.  Hairy white rocks litter the
shoreline, and occasionally an equally hairy black spider can be seen
scuttling between them.  The river lies to the north, while to the
west, south and east lies the bottom of the Great Deep.

57006.name: First Rise (Upper)
description: The top of the first rise is primarily a rough hewn passage, as is
all of the first rise, although towards the western end, the signs of
dwarven stone masons begin to show.  Two massive pillars carved in
{C{^Light Blue Marble{X make a startling contrast to the black granite of
the surrounding walls.  Looking through the archway formed between the
pillars lies the West Hall.

57131.name: The Dawn Path
description: The {Y{#Dawn Path{x curves from the south around to the east here.  The
{Y{#Sunburst Pattern{x in the floor and the freshness in the air indicate
the nearness of this part of Moria to the eastern exit or {Y{#Dawn Gate{x.
The passageway is just over ten feet wide and the walls are covered in
a stacked sandstone, lending to the airy feel of the walkway.

57283.name: An Underground River
description: The gorge continues to narrow with the water rushing rapidly below.
The strange sound to the southwest continues to grow in volume.  White
water sprays upward and a strange luminescent moss grows on the walls
here.  It looks as if it will be a tight squeeze as the gorge heads to
the west.

57069.name: A Downward Stair
description: A wide spiral stair descends through the rock here.  Based on the
dust on the stairs, it appears as if this stair has not been used in a
long time.  Cobwebs hang in the corners, and there is a strange
scuttling sound as if something were drawing back from your light.

57095.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.

57057.name: The Long Stair
description: Standing on the Long Stair, you can look up towards the heights of
the cavern, lost in the inky blackness above.  Below the view is much
the same, the bottom of the cavern lost in the darkness.  The stair is
of cut granite stones and arches so finely crafted it is hard to see
the mortar in the joints.  The stairs themselves are nearly ten feet
wide, easily allowing two or three people to pass at once, but the
lack of walls along the sides is a bit disconcerting.  It might be
best to walk up the center of the stair, just to be safe.  Below you
see the landing called the Second Rise, while the landing at the Third
Rise lurks above.

57188.name: Mine Shaft One
description: A dead end alcove of Moria's Mine Shaft One.  This was the first
vein of mithril discovered by the dwarves of Moria.  It is rumored
that the vein never ran out, but slowed enough that the dwarves found
other more profitable digs.  The walls are of black granite, and the
mithril stands out easily in the light.

57103.name: The Path of Dawn
description: {Y{#The Path of Dawn{x stretches out to the north.  Called the way out
by some, it leads to the Dawn Gate at the eastern end of Moria.  There
is a distinct sunburst pattern replicated down center of the path in
{Y{#Gold veined Marble{x.  Despite the years, the floors are highly
polished and the stone of the walls remains in perfect condition.

57195.name: Mine Shaft Two
description: Shaft Two of Moria seems to be more of a quarry than a mine for
precious minerals.  There is no hint of mithril, and the flecks and
runes marking the mithril halls are absent here.  Instead, the walls
are perfect squares, attesting to the quarrying nature of what was
done here.  This {C{^blue granite{x must have been worth something if the
dwarves were willing to trade in digging for mithril for quarrying
this stuff.  The corridor ends here with another hole in the floor.

57194.name: Mine Shaft Two
description: Shaft Two of Moria seems to be more of a quarry than a mine for
precious minerals.  There is no hint of mithril, and the flecks and
runes marking the mithril halls are absent here.  Instead, the walls
are perfect squares, attesting to the quarrying nature of what was
done here.  This {C{^blue granite{x must have been worth something if the
dwarves were willing to trade in digging for mithril for quarrying
this stuff.  The corridor wraps around a corner traveling from north
to west, following what looks like the clearest vein of the color.

57010.name: {Y{#The West Hall{x (Northeast)
description: This corner of the west hall holds fragments of what looks like
wooden carts and stalls.  There are a couple broken spokes sticking
out of piles of refuse.  Here and there you see strange discs
scattered through the debris, possibly tributes to the skills of
individual craftsmen.  The central column of the hall lies to the
southwest.

57276.name: An Underground River
description: A waterfall crashes from the dark heights of the northern wall into
the river here.  The black water is churned into a white froth, and
sheer granite walls surround you on the north, west and east walls.
The river moves from this pool and begins flowing to the south.  Far
to the south you can see a shoreline and what appears to be an immense
cavern.  The sound at the base of the waterfall is deafening, drowing
out all else.  The only exit is to the south.

57015.name: {Y{#The West Hall{x (Center)
description: The center of the West Hall is dominated by a massive column.  The
column stretches to a height of nearly 50 feet, where it merges with
the arches that span the remainder of the ceiling.  The column is
carved in relief, and is a tribute to the masters who once dwelt
within these depths.  It depicts the commerce that once took place
withing the hall.  Since the time of the carving, there has been much
damage done to the carving, and upon close inspection, not all of the
vandalism is old.  The hall stretches out in all directions.

57274.name: An Underground River
description: The wide underground river moves lazily from east to west.  The
northern shore is a sheer granite wall rising into the inky murk.  To
the south is the shoreline that opens into some immense cavern.  The
sound of rushing water comes from the north and east.  Occasional
white shapes can be seen swimming in the depths of the black water.

57012.name: {Y{#The West Hall{x (Southeast)
description: This corner of the West Hall is barren, as if something had
scavenged what little was here.  There are marks on the floor where
something very heavy was dragged away.  Asides from the thick layer of
dust in this part of the hall, there is little evidence of the
previous inhabitants.  The granite floor is scratched and pitted, but
otherwise, there are no indications on whom the previous inhabitants
may have been.

57235.name: The Bottom of the Great Deep
description: The bottom of the Deep is littered with stone dust and boulders.
Some great earthquake must have caused this fissure long ago.  Granite
walls rise to the south, and the deep continues to the north, east and
west.  Each step seems to echo in the distance, and in the far
distance, water can be heard rushing through somewhere.

57251.name: Bottom of the Great Deep
description: The bottom of the Great Deep.  The stone litter of centuries lies
strewn across the ground.  There is even the occasional glint of what
remains of something metal here or there, but exactly what it once was
is unknown.  The deep continues to the north east and south, while in
the distance water can be heard echoing off the walls of the chasm.

57090.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.  The Soldier's Path lies to the south.

57182.name: Mine Shaft One
description: The twisting passageways of Moria's Mine Shaft One.  This was the
first vein of mithril discovered by the dwarves of Moria.  It is
rumored that the vein never ran out, but slowed enough that the
dwarves found other more profitable digs.  The walls are of black
granite, and the mithril stands out easily in the light.

57201.name: Mine Shaft Two
description: This alcove is more of a cut-out of blue stone.  The walls are
still square and remain the same {C{^light blue{x color.  For some reason,
the dwarves just stopped cutting stone here.  The quarry goes back to
the central shaft to the east.  There is a small hole in the bottom
corner of the west wall leading into a very dark space.  The hole in
no bigger than a couple fingers, but the spot seems to absorb light,
and the {C{^light blue{x walls seem to be just a bit {c{6darker{x here.

57220.name: The Altar of Moradin
description: A Great Mithril Altar in the shape of an anvil stands in the center
of the room.  Iron braziers hang from chains suspended from the
ceiling on either side.  The top of the altar is inscribed with
dwarvish runes.  From the braziers, there still remains a scent of
frankincense that was once burnt within as an offering to their god.
Tapestry rods lacking their once elaborate hangings are suspended from
the walls of the chamber.

57099.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.  South lies Balin's Tomb.

57157.name: A Soldier's House
description: A Spartan Soldier's House, more of a barracks room really.  There
are three narrow stone pallets, beside which are a small stone table.
There is a book niche beside each pallet that may have once held
precious possessions or a lamp.  Stone pegs are scattered about the
wall, obviously for hanging the implements of their trade, as well as
the occasionally needed cloak.  The room has a somewhat oppressive air
to it.

57168.name: The War Hall
description: The War Hall was where the Soldiers of Moria met to discuss matters
of defense of the city, as well as to train.  The hall is large enough
for the whole fighting force to pratice with axes, crossbows or
whatever else they may need.  Scars pit the floor where weapons of the
past made contact with the granite, and the remains of a balista stand
near a low wall with a large opening overlooking a stair in a massive
cavern.

57079.name: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf
description: The Great Hold of Dwarrowdelf stretches out, the ceiling nearly two
hundred feet above is supported by numerous massive columns.  The
columns in this vast room must number in the hundreds.  At one time,
this was the heart of the dwarven city and mines, a place few
outsiders were granted admittance.  It was here that the dwarves
worked their craft, creating armor, weapons and other items of
precious mithril.  The city of Dwarrowdelf was the heart of the
dwarves of Moria.  It is where they raised their families, ran
businesses, and in general lived their lives.  At least until some
disaster befell the mines and city.  It is rumored that they dug too
deep, that they disturbed something deep within the earth.  Something
that in the end, brought the glorious city to its knees.  Now
Dwarrowdelf is merely a tomb.

57207.name: Dorin's Crevasse
description: The walls of the Dorin's Crevasse are natural stone, never having
seen the bite of pick, chisel or drill.  They are uneven granite,
varying from ten to thirty feet wide.  Dorin's fall to the depths must
have been a terrible one.

57247.name: In the Air of the Great Deep
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  It is hard to make out any details
in this void, being able to see neither up, down or to the sides.
Floating in the black nothing of the Great Deep, never knowing when
you may smack into something unpleasant and hard.  Then again, perhaps
it will never happen.  Perhaps there is nothing above or below.
Perhaps none of this is real.  Then again...

57248.name: In the Air of the Great Deep
description: In the air of the Great Deep.  It is hard to make out any details
in this void, being able to see neither up, down or to the sides.
Floating in the black nothing of the Great Deep, never knowing when
you may smack into something unpleasant and hard.  Then again, perhaps
it will never happen.  Perhaps there is nothing above or below.
Perhaps none of this is real.  Then again...

57213.name: A Soldier's House
description: A Spartan Soldier's House, more of a barracks room really.  There
are three narrow stone pallets, beside which are a small stone table.
There is a book niche beside each pallet that may have once held
precious possessions or a lamp.  Stone pegs are scattered about the
wall, obviously for hanging the implements of their trade, as well as
the occasionally needed cloak.  The room has a somewhat oppressive air
to it.

57059.name: The Third Rise
description: The third landing up from the bottom of this enormous cavern is
named the Third Rise.  One of five, climbing into the darkness, this
onw should sit roughly about the center of the cavern.  The landing is
a simple ten foot square, providing a great location for a rest.  The
climb continues above, or there is a stair leading down to the south.
Both the bottom of the cavern and the ceiling are enshrouded by inky
blackness, giving a feeling of floating in the middle of nothing.

57254.name: The Bottom of the Great Deep
description: A A strange corner of the Great Deep.  At the bottom of the chasm
lies this rubble strewn room.  Rock dust and debris lie everywhere,
attesting to the millenia these stones have witnessed.  Inky blackness
surrounds everything and the only sounds that can be heard is the
rushing of water somewhere in the distance.  It is hard to tell
exactly where it is coming from as the sound echoes off the walls.
The floor of the Deep continues to the west and south.

57071.name: The Broad Hall
